Our work identifies shared proteins and pathways as well (Fig. 3). Notably, mitochondrial metabolism is altered in both models. These findings fit well with prior data from our laboratory suggesting that mitochondrial dysfunction is a common downstream mechanism triggered by the interaction of α-synuclein and tau with distinct upstream binding partners
15, 30, 36 . More generally, work from many investigators has implicated mitochondrial dysfunction in the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and related disorders
12, 37, 64 .
